If your license isn’t in English, German, French or Italian, it’s a good idea to carry an International Driving Permit as well. Most rental cars in Switzerland are manual , so if you need an automatic, make sure to reserve it in advance. Cars come with the mandatory motorway vignette (a toll sticker that allows you to use the highways), so you don’t have to worry about buying one separately. If you'd like a more detailed breakdown, I recommend you check out my ultimate guide on renting a car in Switzerland . Rent a car and enjoy your drive through Switzerland. (Photo: Switzerland Tourism: André Meier) Driving rules and the Swiss Vignette Switzerland has strict traffic rules, and they are enforced! Speed limits are 120 km/h on motorways, 80 km/h on rural roads and 50 km/h in cities – unless otherwise indicated. You’ll also need to keep your headlights on at all times, even during the day. Fines are steep for things like speeding , using your phone while driving , or not yielding at a roundabout. So watch out for those pitfalls. The motorway
